titleStmt.title: A true relation of the taking of Grafton House by the Parliaments forces, under the command of Sergeant Major Skipton. With the demands of Sir Iohn Digby upon a surrender. And the resolute answer of Sergeant Major Skipton, to the said demands. As it was sent in a letter from a commander in the service, to his friend in London. With the names of the chiefe commanders that were taken prisoners. The names of the chiefe commanders that were taken prisoners. Sir Iohn Digby. Captaine Iohn Clarke. Lieutenant Lonfield. Quarter master Doswell. Corporall Thorogood. Major Brookebancke. Captaine Longfield. Quater master Collenrigge. Corporall Haynes. And 80 troopers, all with swords, pistols, and carbines.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p:
A true RELATION Of the Taking of Grafton Hou≈øe by the Parliaments Forces, under the Command of Sergeant Major Skipton. With the Demands of Sir IOHN DIGBY upon a ≈øurrender. And the Re≈øolute An≈øwer of Sergeant Major Skipton, to the ≈øaid Demands. As it was ≈øent in a Letter from a Commander in the ≈øervice, to his Friend in London. With the Names of the Chiefe Commanders that were taken Pri≈øoners.
The Names of the Chiefe Commanders that were taken pri≈øoners.
Sir Iohn Digby.
Captaine Iohn Clarke.
Lieutenant Lonfield.
Quarter ma≈øter Do≈øwell.
Corporall Thorogood.
Major Brookebancke.
Captaine Longfield.
Quarter ma≈øter Collenrigge.
Corporall Haynes.
And 80 Troopers, all with ≈øwords, pi≈øtols, and Carbines.
Decemb. 29. Printed for Iohn Wright in the Old-Bailey 1643.

div.head: A True RELATION OF THE Taking of Grafton hou≈øe by the Parliament Forces, under the command of Serjeant Major Skipton.
div.p:
I Thought good to relate unto you, the ≈øervice lately performed here in the≈øe parts. On Thur≈øday night la≈øt, about eight a clocke there was command given, for a party of a thou≈øand foot or thereabouts, to be ready to march the next morning by two of the clocke; whereupon they met at their Rendevouze at Lathbury a mile here hence, where a brave parry of hor≈øe of our owne, and Colonell Norwiches met with us, and were our Van and Reare-gaurd, ≈øo we marcht with foure peeces of Artillery towards Grafton Regis, ≈øix miles off from this place, where we under≈øtood that
our Enemies were inclo≈øed in a ≈øtrong hou≈øe of the Ladie Craines, and the Church of the ≈øame Towne: whereupon we faced it, & leaving it on our right hand, we marcht forward towards Toxiter, as though we had beene bound thitherward. But when wee came within a mile of the ≈øaid Towne of Toxiter, wee met with a party of hor≈øe and foot that came from Northampton for our a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, under the command of Colonell Wettam, whereupon wee faced about, and the party of the Orange Regiment, which before brought up the Reare, then marcht in the Van, and Colonell Williams Forces followed in the Reare of the party that came from Newport. But when we came within ≈øight of the hou≈øe, the old ≈øouldiers of my Lords outmarcht, us, and gave the on≈øet on the hou≈øe very couragiou≈øly, and were as bravely an≈øwered, and by rea≈øon of the ≈øtrength of the walls, and well fortifying of the ≈øame, our Mu≈øquetiers did them ≈ømall injury at that time; whereupon there were two of our peeces planted again≈øt the hou≈øe, and playd upon it, but they did not much annoy them neither. On the Saturday morning the Orange and Greene Regiments relieved my Lords ≈øouldiers, and when any advantage could be gained again≈øt our Enemies, we made u≈øe of it. They within had very long pieces, and could reach us at a great di≈øtance. At our guard we having found a convenient place to plant a piece, made u≈øe of it, & beat down with our Sacre before Saturday night a brea≈øt work on the top of the hou≈øe, which had done us much annoyance, & al≈øo a window whereat they ≈øhot out at us. On Sunday morning we were relieved by tho≈øe Northampton forces, under the command of Colonell Wettam, and about two houres after, he had the guard, they within ≈øounded a parley but through the eagerne≈ø≈øe of the Souldiers the Drum, was ≈øhot, but not ≈ølaine out right,
whereupon they ≈øent out a Trumpet and had parley granted for halfe an houre, and after that another halfe houre, ≈øo then they yeelded them≈øelves pri≈øoners being in number nine≈øcore and ≈øeven be≈øides Officers whereof Sir Iohn Digby was chiefe, there was another Officer of note viz. Major Brookbanck, and diver≈øe Captaines, ≈øome of them men of about 700 li, yeare a piece who≈øe names are to me unknowne. About two of the clocke on Sunday the ≈øouldiers entered the hou≈øe, where they found great and rich plunder, which they had for their paines; In the taking of this hou≈øe wee lo≈øt about 20 men and had hurt 10, be≈øides 9 that were hurt by our own powder, on Chri≈øtmas day before day, order was given to fire our huts which we had made in the field, and for prevention of future inconveniences the hou≈øe was fired al≈øo, ≈øo we marcht with our pri≈øoners (guarded by tho≈øe others forces that a≈øi≈øted us) towards Newport, very weary by rea≈øon of the foulene≈ø≈øe of the weather and deepene≈ø≈øe of the way, but prai≈øed be God we came ≈øafely thither, where we now lye expecting reliefe every day, that we may come and re≈øt our ≈øelves. I thanke God that neither my ≈øelfe nor any of my ≈øouldiers are hurt, nor not one of our Regiment ≈ølaine, notwith≈øtanding we were in great danger and hazard, I be≈øeech God make us thankfull for this pre≈øervation of us, there were ≈øome that came to us on our guard as ≈øpectators, being a ≈øurvayor of the workes, and a Captain of a Troope of Hor≈øe ≈ølaine at one ≈øhot, and al≈øo a Gunner that belonged to the Sacre, in our guard. I pray remember my love to my neighbours, ≈øo with my be≈øt re≈øpect unto you, I re≈øt.

closer.signed: Your loving friend and neighbour W. B.

div.head: Sir John Digby his demands.
div.p: AS we are determined to carry our ≈øelves „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ men, and men of honour; ≈øo if you will plea≈øe to con≈øent to conditions, fit for ≈øuch we ≈øhall ≈øurrender this place unto you.

div.head: The conditions we de≈øire are the≈øe.
div.p: 1. That we may march forth with our Armes, Hor≈øes, and Baggage, and as well tho≈øe that have not borne Armes, as tho≈øe that have, may martch forth to Oxford, in the afore≈øaid manner, without any violence to be offered, till they arrive at Oxford, and have a ≈øafe conduct to Banbury.

2. That both the Souldiers, and the people of the hou≈øe, may have two dayes liberty after the ≈øurrender of the place, to carry away their goods, and the Carts of the Country allowed them in, and the Souldiers may have ≈øix houres liberty, and the hou≈øe to remove Bag and Baggage, if you con≈øent that this be made good, by tho≈øe that are here.

div.head: Major Generall Skiptons An≈øwer.
div.p: 1. To ≈øurrender all your per≈øons Pri≈øoners, and all Arms, Hor≈øes, Standards, Colours, and all Provi≈øions of Warre what≈øoever, withall that is within the hou≈øe.

2. That you deliver all tho≈øe Souldiers of ours, which have been taken pri≈øoners by you, and that if any of our Soldiers, Pri≈øoners, taken by you, have ≈øuffered in any ≈øort by you, that your Souldiers ≈øhall expect the like u≈øage from me.
3. And the≈øe things being performed, I ≈øhall pre≈øerve and ≈øet at liberty, all Women, Children, and ≈øuch other per≈øons as have not bin in armes again≈øt us.
4. And all the≈øe to be performed by you in one houre, or el≈øe pre≈øent adverti≈øement within one quarter of an houre, after the delivery of the≈øe Articles.

list.head: The names of tho≈øe that are taken pri≈øoners, of the Hor≈øe.

div.p: And 80 Troopers all with Swords, Pi≈øtols, and Carbins.

list.head: Be≈øides many other Gentlemen that came voluntarily:

div.p: This is Printed according to Order.
